Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Topology, Geometry, and Data Analysis at The Ohio State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1613094
Principal Investigators: Matthew K. Kahle, Tamal K. Dey, Facundo Memoli, Yusu Wang

This NSF award will support a conference on "Topology, Geometry, and Data Analysis" at Ohio State University in May 2016. Topology and geometry provide novel and robust methods for understanding the shape and structure of complex data sets. This meeting will gather a number of experts in algebraic topology, computational geometry, and related areas, as well as researchers in more applied scientific domains. The main aims are to exchange ideas and to consolidate synergistic activities through fostering collaborations. The organizers will encourage participation by a number of junior participants, introducing this emerging field to the next generation of researchers. Most of the funding will support travel and local expenses of conference participants.

Applied algebraic topology is a rapidly developing area. This meeting will focus on a few of the most promising fronts. It will bring together specialists in computational topology and geometry (mesh generation and manifold reconstruction, persistent homology and cohomology), experts in the theoretical underpinnings (algebraic and categorical views of persistent homology, stability and inference), and researchers working in more applied areas (mathematical neuroscience, molecular biology, material science). The organizers are especially interested in new collaborations across disciplines, for example in applying topological methods to detect previously unknown structure in biological datasets, so the focus of this meeting is coherent but broad. The website for this conference can be found here http://www.tgda.osu.edu/tgda-conf-osu.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported a conference on Topology, Geometry, and Data Analysis (TGDA), at Ohio State University. May 16–20, 2016. The conference was hosted by the Mathematical Biosciences Institute (MBI). Additional support was provided by Ohio State's Mathematics Research Institute (MRI). The conference was organized by Tamal Dey, Matthew Kahle, Facundo Mémoli, and Yusu Wang.
In recent years, topological and geometric methods have emerged as new promising tools for analyzing complex data. To broaden the scope of these methods, we need stronger cooperation among mathematical fields such as algebraic topology, and algorithmic developments such as those in computational geometry. We also need tighter interaction with applied scientific domains. This conference brought together researchers from mathematics and computational and applied sciences in order to exchange ideas and foster collaborations.
There were 22 invited talks. Of these, almost all of the speakers signed waivers agreeing to have their video posted online, hosted by the MBI. These videos are all hosted for streaming by MBI. A permanent website dedicated to the conference, with abstracts and links to the videos of the talks, can be found at http://www.tgda.osu.edu/tgda-conf-osu.html
Through this award, we were able to offer travel support for all the invited speakers. Additionally, the award sponsored the travel of 22 young researchers (within 5 years of their PhD). In total there were 67 registered participants.
Several researchers also presented posters at a poster session and reception on Monday evening, and the posters remained up for the rest of the week, prompting many interesting conversations. Several important mathematical breakthroughs were presented at the meeting. These will lay theoretical foundations for the next few years in this area. Applications were also presented, including to brain science, to time series analysis, and to computational biology.
There was a small amount left in the grant after the conference. With permission from the program officer at NSF and sponsored program officer at Ohio State, this was re-budgeted to support a mini-course by Patrizio Frosini, April 3–7, 2017 on "Some new results in two-dimensional and group-invariant persistent homology." http://www.tgda.osu.edu/mini-course-frosini.html
By all measures, the conference was a success. Cutting edge research was disseminated, and several new collaborations and projects were initiated at the meeting. Early-career researchers were exposed to new ideas and introduced to the experts in this rapidly developing area. We expect that the impact of the conference will continue to be felt for the next several years.
